member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLog
member.summary: Class is similar to the System.Diagnostics.EventLog in the full framework with a few differences. 1. Since CE.Net and PPC have no event log we write the log to the application root directory as an XML file 2. Every Application will have it's own log. There will not be one log system/device wide 3. Attempted to keep as close as possible to the full framework class but some things are missing

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.Data
member.summary: Gets the binary data associated with the entry.
member.value: An array of bytes that holds the binary data associated with the entry.
member.remarks: Getting this property creates an array that holds a copy of the entry's event-specific binary data. Event-specific data is sometimes used to store information that the application will process independently of the Event Viewer, for example, to make reports from the log file.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.EntryType
member.summary: Gets the event type of this entry.
member.value: The EventLogEntryType that indicates the event type associated with the entry in the event log. This is usually used to indicate the severity of the event log entry.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.EventID
member.summary: Gets the application-specific event identifier of this event entry.
member.value: The application-specific identifier for the event.
member.remarks: Event identifiers, together with the event source, uniquely identify an event.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.Index
member.summary: Gets the index of this entry in the event log.
member.value: The index of this entry in the event log.
member.remarks: This number is not necessarily zero based.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.MachineName
member.summary: Gets the name of the computer on which this entry was generated.
member.value: The name of the computer that contains the event log.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.Message
member.summary: Gets the localized message associated with this event entry.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.Source
member.summary: Gets the name of the application that generated this event.
member.remarks: The event source indicates what logged the event. It is often the name of the application, or the name of a subcomponent of the application if the application is large. Applications and services usually write to (and therefore are sources for) the Application log or a custom log. Device drivers usually write to the System log.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.TimeGenerated
member.summary: Gets the local time at which this event was generated.
member.value: A DateTime that represents the local time at which this event was generated.
member.remarks: This member holds the time that an event was generated. This might not be the same as the time when the event information was written to the event log. For the latter, read the TimeWritten property.Thereâ€™s almost always going to be a lag between the time something happens and the time it is logged, if only milliseconds. Usually, it is more important to know when the event was generated, unless you want to see if there is a significant lag in logging. That can happen if your log files are on a different server and you are experiencing a bottleneck.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntry.TimeWritten
member.summary: Gets the local time at which this event was written to the log.
member.value: A DateTime that represents the local time at which this event was written to the log.
member.remarks: This member holds the time that an event's information is written to the event log. This might not be the same time as when the event was generated. For the latter, read the TimeGenerated property.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType
member.summary: Specifies the event type of an event log entry.
member.remarks: The type of an event log entry is used to indicate the severity of an event log entry. Each event must be of a single type, which the application indicates when it reports the event.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.Error
member.summary: An error event. This indicates a significant problem the user should know about; usually a loss of functionality or data.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.FailureAudit
member.summary: A failure audit event. This indicates a security event that occurs when an audited access attempt fails; for example, a failed attempt to open a file.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.Information
member.summary: An information event. This indicates a significant, successful operation.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.SuccessAudit
member.summary: A success audit event. This indicates a security event that occurs when an audited access attempt is successful; for example, logging on successfully.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.Warning
member.summary: A warning event. This indicates a problem that is not immediately significant, but that may signify conditions that could cause future problems.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo.GetVersionInfo(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a representing the version information associated with the specified file.
member.param: The fully qualified path and name of the file to retrieve the version information for.
member.returns: A containing information about the file. If the file information was not found, the contains only the name of the file requested.
member.exception: The file specified cannot be found.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo.FileName
member.summary: Gets the name of the file that this instance of describes.
member.value: The name of the file described by this instance of .

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo.FileMajorPart
member.summary: Gets the major part of the version number.
member.value: A value representing the major part of the version number.
member.remarks:
Typically, a version number is displayed as "major number.minor number.build number.private part number". A file version number is a 64-bit number that holds the version number for a file as follows:
The first 16 bits are the number.
The next 16 bits are the number.
The third set of 16 bits are the number.
The last 16 bits are the number. This property gets the first set of 16 bits.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo.FileMinorPart
member.summary: Gets the minor part of the version number.
member.value: A value representing the minor part of the version number of the file.
member.remarks:
Typically, a version number is displayed as "major number.minor number.build number.private part number". A file version number is a 64-bit number that holds the version number for a file as follows:
The first 16 bits are the number.
The next 16 bits are the number.
The third set of 16 bits are the number.
The last 16 bits are the number. This property gets the second set of 16 bits.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.FileVersionInfo.FileBuildPart
member.summary: Gets the build number of the file.
member.value: A value representing the build number of the file.
member.remarks:
Typically, a version number is displayed as "major number.minor number.build number.private part number". A file version number is a 64-bit number that holds the version number for a file as follows:
The first 16 bits are the number.
The next 16 bits are the number.
The third set of 16 bits are the number.
The last 16 bits are the number. This property gets the third set of 16 bits.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process
member.summary: Provides access to local and remote processes and enables you to start and stop local system processes.
member.remarks: A component provides access to a process that is running on a computer. A process, in the simplest terms, is a running application. A thread is the basic unit to which the operating system allocates processor time. A thread can execute any part of the code of the process, including parts currently being executed by another thread.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process class.

member.summary: Releases all resources used by the .
member.remarks: Calling Dispose allows the resources used by the to be reallocated for other purposes.

member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by the and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

Returns a new component, given the identifier of a process on the device.

member.summary: Starts the process resource that is specified by the parameter containing process start information (for example, the file name of the process to start) and associates the resource with a new OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process component.
member.param: The OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo that contains the information that is used to start the process, including the file name and any command line arguments.
member.returns: A new OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process component that is associated with the process resource, or null if no process resource is started (for example, if an existing process is reused).

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.Start
member.summary: Starts (or reuses) the process resource that is specified by the OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.StartInfo property of this OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process component and associates it with the component.
member.returns: true if a process resource is started; false if no new process resource is started (for example, if an existing process is reused).

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.Kill
member.summary: Immediately stops the associated process.
member.exception: The associated process could not be terminated.
The process has already exited.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.WaitForExit
member.summary: Instructs the component to wait indefinitely for the associated process to exit.
member.remarks: WaitForExit is used to make the current thread wait until the associated process terminates. This overload of instructs the component to wait an infinite amount of time for the process to exit. This can cause an application to stop responding.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.WaitForExit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Instructs the component to wait the specified number of milliseconds for the associated process to exit.
member.param: The amount of time, in milliseconds, to wait for the associated process to exit. The maximum is the largest possible value of a 32-bit integer, which represents infinity to the operating system.
member.returns: true if the associated process has exited; otherwise, false.

member.summary:
Gets a new component and associates it with the currently active process.
New in v1.1
member.returns: A new component associated with the process resource that is running the calling application.
member.remarks: Use this method to create a new Process instance and associate it with the process resource on the local computer.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.GetCurrentThread
member.summary: This function returns a pseudohandle for the current thread.
member.returns: The return value is a pseudohandle for the current thread.

remarks.p: A pseudohandle is a special constant that is interpreted as the current thread handle.
The calling thread can use this handle to specify itself whenever a thread handle is required.This handle has the maximum possible access to the thread object.

The function cannot be used by one thread to create a handle that can be used by other threads to refer to the first thread. The handle is always interpreted as referring to the thread that is using it.
The pseudohandle need not be closed when it is no longer needed. Calling the CloseHandle function with this handle has no effect.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.Handle
member.summary: Returns the associated process's native handle.
member.value: The handle that the operating system assigned to the associated process when the process was started. The system uses this handle to keep track of process attributes.

member.summary: Gets the unique identifier for the associated process.
member.remarks: The system-generated unique identifier of the process that is referenced by this instance.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.HasExited

member.remarks: true if the operating system process referenced by the component has terminated; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.ExitCode
member.summary: Gets the value that the associated process specified when it terminated.
member.remarks: The code that the associated process specified when it terminated.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.StartInfo
member.summary: Gets or sets the properties to pass to the method of the .
member.value: The that represents the data with which to start the process. These arguments include the name of the executable file or document used to start the process.
member.exception: The value that specifies the is null.
member.remarks: StartInfo represents the set of parameters to use to start a process. When is called, the is used to specify the process to start. The only necessary StartInfo member to set is the property. The property does not need to represent an executable file. It can be of any file type for which the extension has been associated with an application installed on the system. For example the FileName can have a .txt extension if you have associated text files with an editor, such as Notepad, or it can have a .pwd if you have associated .pwd files with a word processing tool, such as Microsoft Pocket Word.

member.name: E:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.Process.Exited
member.summary: Occurs when a process exits.
member.remarks: Note that in this partial implementation the Exited event will only be raised when a is explictly Killed. The class will not watch created processes unless you use the method.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo
member.summary: Specifies a set of values used when starting a process.
member.remarks: is used in conjunction with the component. When you start a process using the Process class, you have access to process information in addition to that available when attaching to a running process. You can use the class for greater control over the process you start. You must at least set the property, either manually or using the constructor. The file name is any application or document. Here a document is defined to be any file type that has an open or default action associated with it.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class without specifying a file name with which to start the process.
member.remarks:
You must set at least the property before starting the process. The file name is any application or document. In this case, a document is defined to be any file type that has an open or default action associated with it.
Optionally, you can also set other properties before starting the process. The property supplies actions to take, such as "print", with the file indicated in the property. The property supplies a way to pass command line arguments to the file when the system opens it.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class and specifies a file name such as an application or document with which to start the process.
member.param: An application or document with which to start a process.
member.remarks: The file name is any application or document. In this case, a document is defined to be any file type that has an open or default action associated with it.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class and specifies an application file name with which to start the process, as well as a set of command line arguments to pass to the application.
member.param: An application with which to start a process.
Command line arguments to pass to the application when the process starts.
member.remarks:
The file name is any application or document. In this case, a document is defined to be any file type that has an open or default action associated with it.
You can change the or properties after calling this constructor, up to the time that the process starts. After you start the process, changing these values has no effect.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo.Arguments
member.summary: Gets or sets the set of command line arguments to use when starting the application.
member.value: File type-specific arguments that the system can associate with the application specified in the property. The default is an empty string ("").

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo.FileName
member.summary: Gets or sets the application or document to start.
member.value: The name of the application to start, or the name of a document of a file type that is associated with an application and that has a default open action available to it. The default is an empty string ("").
member.remarks:
You must set at least the FileName property before starting the process. The file name is any application or document. Here a document is defined to be any file type that has an open or default action associated with it.
The set of file types available to you depends in part on the value of the property. If is true, you are able to start any document and perform operations on the file, such as printing, with the component. When is false, you are able to start only executables with the component.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo.UseShellExecute
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to use the operating system shell to start the process.
member.value: true to use the shell when starting the process; otherwise, the process is created directly from the executable file. The default is true.
member.remarks: When you use the operating system shell to start processes, you are able to start any document (which is any registered file type associated with an executable that has a default open action) and perform operations on the file, such as printing, with the component. When UseShellExecute is false, you are able to start only executables with the component.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo.Verb
member.summary: Gets or sets the verb to use when opening the application or document specified by the property.
member.value: The action to take with the file that the process opens. The default is an empty string ("").
member.remarks: Each file name extension has its own set of verbs. For example, the "print" verb will print a document specified using . The default verb can be specified using an empty string ("").

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo.WindowStyle
member.summary:
Gets or sets the window state to use when the process is started.
Not currently supported.
member.value: A that indicates whether the process is started in a window that is maximized, minimized, normal (neither maximized nor minimized), or not visible. The default is normal.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle
member.summary: Specified how a new window should appear when the system starts a process.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle.Hidden
member.summary: The hidden window style. A window can be either visible or hidden. The system displays a hidden window by not drawing it. If a window is hidden, it is effectively disabled. A hidden window can process messages from the system or from other windows, but it cannot process input from the user or display output. Frequently, an application may keep a new window hidden while it customizes the window's appearance, and then make the window style Normal .

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle.Maximized
member.summary: The maximized window style. By default, the system enlarges a maximized window so that it fills the screen or, in the case of a child window, the parent window's client area. If the window has a title bar, the system automatically moves it to the top of the screen or to the top of the parent window's client area. Also, the system disables the window's sizing border and the window-positioning capability of the title bar so that the user cannot move the window by dragging the title bar.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle.Minimized
member.summary: The minimized window style. By default, the system reduces a minimized window to the size of its taskbar button and moves the minimized window to the taskbar.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle.Normal
member.summary: The normal, visible window style. The system displays a window with Normal style on the screen, in a default location. If a window is visible, the user can supply input to the window and view the window's output. Frequently, an application may initialize a new window to the Hidden style while it customizes the window's appearance, and then make the window style Normal.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings
member.summary: Used for manipulating all settings of a Port class

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.#ctor
member.summary: Create a DetailedPortSettings class

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.Init
member.summary: These are the default port settings override Init() to create new defaults (i.e. common handshaking)

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.BasicSettings
member.summary: Basic port settings

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.OutCTS
member.summary: Specifies if the CTS (clear-to-send) signal is monitored for output flow control. If this member is TRUE and CTS is turned off, output is suspended until CTS is sent again.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.OutDSR
member.summary: Specifies if the DSR (data-set-ready) signal is monitored for output flow control. If this member is TRUE and DSR is turned off, output is suspended until DSR is sent again.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.DTRControl
member.summary: Specifies the DTR (data-terminal-ready) flow control.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.DSRSensitive
member.summary: Specifies if the communications driver is sensitive to the state of the DSR signal. If this member is TRUE, the driver ignores any bytes received, unless the DSR modem input line is high.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.TxContinueOnXOff
member.summary: Specifies if transmission stops when the input buffer is full and the driver has transmitted the XoffChar character. If this member is TRUE, transmission continues after the input buffer has come within XoffLim bytes of being full and the driver has transmitted the XoffChar character to stop receiving bytes. If this member is FALSE, transmission does not continue until the input buffer is within XonLim bytes of being empty and the driver has transmitted the XonChar character to resume reception.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.OutX
member.summary: Specifies if XON/XOFF flow control is used during transmission. If this member is TRUE, transmission stops when the XoffChar character is received and starts again when the XonChar character is received.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.InX
member.summary: Specifies if XON/XOFF flow control is used during reception. If this member is TRUE, the XoffChar character is sent when the input buffer comes within XoffLim bytes of being full, and the XonChar character is sent when the input buffer comes within XonLim bytes of being empty

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.ReplaceErrorChar
member.summary: Specifies if bytes received with parity errors are replaced with the character specified by the ErrorChar member. If this member is TRUE and the fParity member is TRUE, replacement occurs.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.RTSControl
member.summary: Specifies the RTS (request-to-send) flow control. If this value is zero, the default is RTS_CONTROL_HANDSHAKE. The following table shows possible values for this member.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.DiscardNulls
member.summary: Specifies if null bytes are discarded. If this member is TRUE, null bytes are discarded when received.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.AbortOnError
member.summary: Specifies if read and write operations are terminated if an error occurs. If this member is TRUE, the driver terminates all read and write operations with an error status if an error occurs. The driver will not accept any further communications operations until the application has acknowledged the error by calling the ClearError function.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.XonChar
member.summary: Specifies the value of the XON character for both transmission and reception

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.XoffChar
member.summary: Specifies the value of the XOFF character for both transmission and reception.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.ErrorChar
member.summary: Specifies the value of the character used to replace bytes received with a parity error.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.EOFChar
member.summary: Specifies the value of the character used to signal the end of data.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.Serial.DetailedPortSettings.EVTChar
member.summary: Specifies the value of the character used to signal an event.

member.summary: A common implementation of DetailedPortSettings for non handshaking

Buffer that receives the data read from the file.
Number of bytes to be read from the file.
number of bytes read. ReadFile sets this value to zero before doing any work or error checking.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.IO.FileShare
member.summary: CreateFile file share mode

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.FileShare.None
member.summary: Declines sharing of the current file. Any request to open the file (by this process or another process) will fail until the file is closed.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.FileShare.Read
member.summary: Allows subsequent opening of the file for reading. If this flag is not specified, any request to open the file for reading (by this process or another process) will fail until the file is closed. However, if this flag is specified additional permissions might still be needed to access the file.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.FileShare.Write
member.summary: Allows subsequent opening of the file for writing. If this flag is not specified, any request to open the file for writing (by this process or another process) will fail until the file is closed. However, if this flag is specified additional permissions might still be needed to access the file.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.FileShare.ReadWrite
member.summary: Allows subsequent opening of the file for reading or writing. If this flag is not specified, any request to open the file for writing or reading (by this process or another process) will fail until the file is closed. However, if this flag is specified additional permissions might still be needed to access the file.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.IO.FileShare.Delete
member.summary: Allows the file to be deleted.

member.summary: This function initiates the hashing of a stream of data. It creates and returns to the calling application a handle to a cryptographic service provider (CSP) hash object. This handle is used in subsequent calls to the CryptHashData function and CryptHashSessionKey function to hash streams of data and session keys.
member.remarks: raCrypto, mca / worked on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptDecrypt(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Boolean,System.UInt32,System.Byte[],System.UInt32@)

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptDeriveKey(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: This function generates cryptographic session keys derived from base data. This function guarantees that all keys generated from the same base data are identical, provided the same cryptographic service provider (CSP) and algorithms are used. The base data can be a password or any other user data. This function is the same as the CryptGenKey function, except that the generated session keys are derived from base data instead of being random. The CryptDeriveKey function can only generate session keys and cannot be used to generate public/private key pairs. A handle to the session key is returned in the phKey parameter. This handle can then be used with any CryptoAPI functions that require key handles.
member.remarks: raCrypto, mca / works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptDestroyHash(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: This function destroys the hash object referenced by the hHash parameter. Once a hash object has been destroyed, it can no longer be used and its handle is useless from then on. All hash objects should be destroyed with the CryptDestroyHash function when the application is finished with them.
member.remarks: raCrypto / worked on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptDestroyKey(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: This function releases the handle referenced by the hKey parameter. Once a key handle has been released, it becomes invalid and cannot be used again. If the handle refers to a session key, or to a public key that has been imported into the cryptographic service provider (CSP) through CryptImportKey, the CryptDestroyKey function destroys the key and frees the memory that the key occupied. Many CSPs scrub the memory where the key was held before freeing it. On the other hand, if the handle refers to a public/private key pair obtained from the CryptGetUserKey function, the underlying key pair is not destroyed by the CryptDestroyKey function. Only the handle is destroyed.
member.remarks: raCrypto / works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptExportKey(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Byte[],System.UInt32@)
member.summary: This function exports cryptographic keys from of a cryptographic service provider (CSP) in a secure manner. The caller passes to the CryptImportKey function a handle to the key to be exported and gets a key binary large object (BLOB). This key BLOB can be sent over a nonsecure transport or stored in a nonsecure storage location. The key BLOB is useless until the intended recipient uses the CryptImportKey function, which imports the key into the recipient's CSP.
member.remarks: mca / works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptGenKey(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: This function generates a random cryptographic session key or a public/private key pair for use with the cryptographic service provider (CSP) module. The function returns a handle to the key in the phKey parameter. This handle can then be used as needed with any of the other CryptoAPI functions requiring a key handle. When calling this function, the application must specify the algorithm. Because this algorithm type is kept bundled with the key, the application does not need to specify the algorithm later when the actual cryptographic operations are performed.
member.remarks: mca / works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptGenRandom(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: This function fills a buffer with random bytes.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptGetUserKey(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: This function retrieves a handle to a permanent user key pair, such as the user's signature key pair. This function also retrieves a handle to one of a user's two public/private key pairs. Only the owner of the public/private key pairs uses the function and only when the handle to a cryptographic service provider (CSP) and its associated key container is available. Use the CryptAcquireCertificatePrivateKey function if the user's certificate is available, but not the CSP handle.
member.remarks: mca / works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptHashData(System.IntPtr,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: This function adds data to a specified hash object. This function and the CryptHashSessionKey function can be called multiple times to compute the hash on long streams or on discontinuous streams. Before calling this function, the CryptCreateHash function must be called to create a handle to a hash object.
member.remarks: raCrypto, mca / worked on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptHashSessionKey(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: This function computes the cryptographic hash of a session key object. This function can be called multiple times with the same hash handle to compute the hash of multiple keys. Calls to the CryptHashSessionKey function can be interspersed with calls to the CryptHashData function. Before calling this function, the CryptCreateHash function must be called to get a handle to a hash object.
member.remarks: works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptImportKey(System.IntPtr,System.Byte[],System.UInt32,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: This function transfers a cryptographic key from a key binary large object (BLOB) to the cryptographic service provider (CSP). This function can be used to import an Schannel session key, regular session key, public key, or public/private key pair. For all but the public key, the key or key pair is encrypted.
member.remarks: mca / works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptProtectData(OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.CRYPTOAPI_BLOB@,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.CRYPTOAPI_BLOB@)
member.summary: This function performs encryption on the data in a DATA_BLOB structure. Typically, only a user with the same logon credentials as the encrypter can decrypt the data. In addition, the encryption and decryption usually must be done on the same computer. For information about exceptions, see the Remarks section. Note An untrusted application can call the CryptProtectData function. The call will fail only if CRYPTPROTECT_SYSTEM is specified for the dwFlags parameter.
member.remarks: works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptReleaseContext(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: This function releases the handle to a cryptographic service provider (CSP) and the key container. At each call to this function, the reference count on the CSP is reduced by one. When the reference count reaches zero, the context is fully released and it can no longer be used by any function in the application. The application calls this function when it is finished using the CSP. After this function is called, the CSP handle specified by the hProv parameter is no longer valid; however, the function does not destroy either the key container or any key pairs.
member.remarks: raCrypto / works on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptSetHashParam(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.Byte[],System.UInt32)

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptSetKeyParam(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.Byte[],System.UInt32)
member.summary: This function customizes various aspects of a key's operations. The values set by this function are not persisted to memory and are used only within a single session. The Microsoft cryptographic service providers (CSPs) do not allow setting the values for key exchange or signature keys; however, custom providers may define parameters that can be set on these keys.
member.remarks: worked on smartPhone

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptSetProvider(System.String,System.UInt32)
member.summary: This function specifies the current user default cryptographic service provider (CSP). Typical applications do not use this function. It is intended for use solely by administrative applications. If a current user's default provider is set, that default provider is acquired by any call by that user to the CryptAcquireContext function specifying a dwProvType provider type but not a CSP name.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Security.Cryptography.NativeMethods.Crypto.CryptSetProviderEx(System.String,System.UInt32,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: This function specifies the default cryptographic service provider (CSP) for the current user or the local device. If a current user's default provider is set, that default provider is acquired by any call by that user to the CryptAcquireContext function specifying a dwProvType provider type but not a CSP name. If a local computer default is set, calls to the CryptAcquireContext function by a user not having a current user default set and not specifying a CSP result in the use of the local computer's default CSP. Typical applications do not use this function. It is intended for use solely by administrative applications.

member.summary: The owner of the monitor, or null if it's not owned by any thread.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.lockCount
member.summary: Number of levels of locking (0 for an unowned monitor, 1 after a single call to Enter, etc).

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.stateLock
member.summary: Object to be used as a monitor for state changing.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.waitPulseEvent
member.summary: AutoResetEvent used to implement Wait/Pulse/PulseAll. Initially not signalled, so that a call to Wait will block until the first pulse.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.waitCounter
member.summary: Number of threads waiting on this monitor.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.enterExitEvent
member.summary: Event used for Enter/Exit. Initially signalled to allow the first thread to come in.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new monitor, not owned by any thread.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.Enter
member.summary: Enters the monitor (locks it), blocking until the lock is held. If the monitor is already held by the current thread, its lock count is incremented.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.TryEnter
member.summary: Attempts to enter the monitor (locking it) but does not block if the monitor is already owned.
member.returns: Whether or not the current thread now owns the monitor.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.Exit
member.summary: Releases a level of locking, unlocking the monitor itself if the lock count becomes 0.
member.exception: If the current thread does not own the monitor.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.Pulse
member.summary: Pulses the monitor once - a single waiting thread will be released and continue its execution after the current thread has exited the monitor. Unlike Pulse on the normal framework, no guarantee is made about which thread is woken.
member.exception: If the current thread does not own the monitor.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.PulseAll
member.summary: Pulses the monitor such that all waiting threads are woken up. All threads will then try to regain the lock on this monitor. No order for regaining the lock is specified.
member.exception: If the current thread does not own the monitor.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Threading.MonitorEx.Wait
member.summary: Relinquishes the lock on this monitor (whatever the lock count is) and waits for the monitor to be pulsed. After the monitor has been pulsed, the thread blocks again until it has regained the lock (at which point it will have the same lock count as it had before), and then the method returns.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Threading.SynchronizationLockException
member.summary: Exception thrown by when threading rules are violated (usually due to an operation being invoked on a monitor not owned by the current thread).

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapFileHeader
member.summary: This structure contains information about the type, size, and layout of a file that containing a device-independent bitmap (DIB).
member.remarks: Wraps the native BITMAPFILEHEADER structure

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapFileHeader.Type
member.summary: Specifies the file type. It must be BM.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapFileHeader.Size
member.summary: Specifies the size, in bytes, of the bitmap file.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapFileHeader.OffBits
member.summary: Specifies the offset, in bytes, from the BitmapFileHeader structure to the bitmap bits.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader
member.summary: Contains information about the dimensions and color format of a device-independent bitmap (DIB).
member.remarks: Wrapper for Win32 BITMAPINFOHEADER structure

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.Size
member.summary: Specifies the number of bytes required by the structure.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.Width
member.summary: Specifies the width of the bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.Height
member.summary: Specifies the height of the bitmap, in pixels. If biHeight is positive, the bitmap is a bottom-up DIB and its origin is the lower-left corner. If biHeight is negative, the bitmap is a top-down DIB and its origin is the upper-left corner. If biHeight is negative, indicating a top-down DIB, biCompression must be either BI_RGB or BI_BITFIELDS. Top-down DIBs cannot be compressed.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.Planes
member.summary: Specifies the number of planes for the target device. This value must be set to 1.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.BitCount
member.summary: Specifies the number of bits per pixel. The biBitCount member determines the number of bits that define each pixel and the maximum number of colors in the bitmap.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.Compression
member.summary: Specifies the type of compression for a compressed bottom-up bitmap (top-down DIBs cannot be compressed).

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.SizeImage
member.summary: Specifies the size, in bytes, of the image. This may be set to zero for BI_RGB bitmaps.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.XPelsPerMeter
member.summary: Specifies the horizontal resolution, in pixels per meter, of the target device for the bitmap. An application can use this value to select a bitmap from a resource group that best matches the characteristics of the current device.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.YPelsPerMeter
member.summary: Specifies the vertical resolution, in pixels per meter, of the target device for the bitmap

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.ClrUsed
member.summary: Specifies the number of color indexes in the color table that are actually used by the bitmap. If this value is zero, the bitmap uses the maximum number of colors corresponding to the value of the biBitCount member for the compression mode specified by biCompression.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.BitmapInfoHeader.ClrImportant
member.summary: Specifies the number of color indexes required for displaying the bitmap. If this value is zero, all colors are required.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Win32.Core.CreateMutex(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: This function creates a named or unnamed mutex object
member.param: Ignored. Must be null

Boolean that specifies the initial owner of the mutex object. If this value is true and the caller created the mutex, the calling thread obtains ownership of the mutex object. Otherwise, the calling thread does not obtain ownership of the mutex.
String specifying the name of the mutex object.
member.returns: A handle to the mutex object indicates success. If the named mutex object existed before the function call, the function returns a handle to the existing object. A return value of null indicates failure.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.TimeZoneInformation.Bias
member.summary: Specifies the current bias, in minutes, for local time translation on this computer.
member.remarks:
The bias is the difference, in minutes, between Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) and local time. All translations between UTC and local time are based on the following formula:
UTC = local time + bias

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.TimeZoneInformation.StandardName
member.summary: Name associated with standard time on this device.
member.remarks: For example, this member could contain â€œESTâ€ to indicate Eastern Standard Time.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.TimeZoneInformation.StandardDate
member.summary: The date and local time when the transition from Daylight time to Standard time occurs.
member.remarks:
This member supports two date formats. Absolute format specifies an exact date and time when standard time begins. In this form, the wYear, wMonth, wDay, wHour, wMinute, wSecond, and wMilliseconds members of the SYSTEMTIME structure are used to specify an exact date.
Day-in-month format is specified by setting the wYear member to zero, setting the wDayOfWeek member to an appropriate weekday, and using a wDay value in the range 1 through 5 to select the correct day in the month. Using this notation, the first Sunday in April can be specified, as can the last Thursday in October (5 is equal to â€œthe lastâ€).

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.TimeZoneInformation.StandardBias
member.summary: Specifies a bias value to be used during local time translations that occur during standard time.
member.remarks: This member is ignored if a value for the StandardDate member is not supplied. This value is added to the value of the Bias member to form the bias used during standard time. In most time zones, the value of this member is zero.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Win32.TimeZoneInformation.DaylightBias
member.summary: Specifies a bias value to be used during local time translations that occur during daylight time.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Win32.Registry
member.summary: Supplies the base RegistryKeys that access values and subkeys in the registry.
member.remarks:
This class provides the set of standard root keys found in the registry on machines running Windows CE. The registry is a storage facility for information about applications and default system settings. For example, applications can use the registry for storing information that needs to be preserved once the application is closed, and access that same information when the application is reloaded. For instance, you can store color preferences, screen locations, or the size of the window. The keys exposed by Registry are:
CurrentUserStores information about user preferences.
LocalMachineStores configuration information for the local machine.
ClassesRootStores information about types (and classes) and their properties.
UsersStores information about the default user configuration. Once you have identified the root key under which you want to store/retrieve information from the registry, you can use the RegistryKey class to add or remove subkeys, and manipulate the values for a given key.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Registry.LocalMachine
member.summary: Contains the configuration data for the local machine. This field reads the Windows registry base key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Registry.CurrentUser
member.summary: Contains information about the current user preferences. This field reads the Windows registry base key HKEY_CURRENT_USER.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Registry.ClassesRoot
member.summary: Defines the types (or classes) of documents and the properties associated with those types. This field reads the Windows registry base key HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Registry.Users
member.summary: Contains information about the default user configuration. This field reads the Windows registry base key HKEY_USERS.

Specifies the zero-based offset to the value to be retrieved. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra window memory, minus four; for example, if you specified 12 or more bytes of extra memory, a value of 8 would be an index to the third 32-bit integer.
member.returns: The requested 32-bit value indicates success. Zero indicates failure.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.MoveWindow(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This function changes the position and dimensions of the specified window. For a top-level window, the position and dimensions are relative to the upper-left corner of the screen. For a child window, they are relative to the upper-left corner of the parent window's client area.
member.param: Handle to the window.
Specifies the new position of the left side of the window.
Specifies the new position of the top of the window.
Specifies the new width of the window.
Specifies the new height of the window.
member.returns: Nonzero indicates success. Zero indicates failure.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.PostMessage(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Places a message in the message queue associated with the thread that created the specified window and then returns without waiting for the thread to process the message.
member.param: Handle to the window whose window procedure is to receive the message.
Specifies the message to be posted.
Specifies additional message-specific information.
Specifies additional message-specific information.
member.returns: Nonzero indicates success. Zero indicates failure.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.SetWindowLong(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Changes an attribute of the specified window.
member.param: Handle to the window and, indirectly, the class to which the window belongs.
Specifies the zero-based offset to the value to be set.
Specifies the replacement value.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.EnableWindow(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: enables or disables mouse and keyboard input to the specified window or control. When input is disabled, the window does not receive input such as mouse clicks and key presses. When input is enabled, the window receives all input.
member.param: Handle to the window to be enabled or disabled.
Boolean that specifies whether to enable or disable the window. If this parameter is TRUE, the window is enabled. If the parameter is FALSE, the window is disabled.
member.returns: Nonzero indicates that the window was previously disabled. Zero indicates that the window was not previously disabled.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.RegisterWindowMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Defines a new window message that is guaranteed to be unique throughout the system. The returned message value can be used when calling the SendMessage or PostMessage function.
member.param: String that specifies the message to be registered.
member.returns: A message identifier in the range 0xC000 through 0xFFFF indicates that the message is successfully registered. Zero indicates failure.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.SetFocus(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Sets the keyboard focus to the specified window. All subsequent keyboard input is directed to this window. The window, if any, that previously had the keyboard focus loses it.
member.param: Handle to the window that will receive the keyboard input. If this parameter is NULL, keystrokes are ignored.
member.returns: The handle to the window that previously had the keyboard focus indicates success. NULL indicates that the hWnd parameter is invalid or the window is not associated with the calling thread's message queue.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.SetForegroundWindow(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Puts the thread that created the specified window into the foreground and activates the window.
member.param: Handle to the window that should be activated and brought to the foreground.
member.returns: Nonzero indicates that the window was brought to the foreground. Zero indicates that the window was not brought to the foreground.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended
member.summary: Specifies the extended style of the window. This parameter can be one of the values

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_ACCEPTFILES
member.summary: Specifies that a window created with this style accepts drag-drop files.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_APPWINDOW
member.summary: Forces a top-level window onto the taskbar when the window is visible.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_CLIENTEDGE
member.summary: Specifies that a window has a border with a sunken edge.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_DLGMODALFRAME
member.summary: Creates a window that has a double border; the window can, optionally, be created with a title bar by specifying the WS_CAPTION style in the dwStyle parameter.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_LEFT
member.summary: Creates a window that has generic "left-aligned" properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_LEFTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading order alignment, the vertical scroll bar (if present) is to the left of the client area. For other languages, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_LTRREADING
member.summary: The window text is displayed using left-to-right reading-order properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_MDICHILD
member.summary: Creates an MDI child window.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_NOACTIVATE
member.summary: A top-level window created with this style cannot be activated. If a child window has this style, tapping it does not cause its top-level parent to be activated. A window that has this style receives stylus events, but neither it nor its child windows can get the focus. Supported in Windows CE versions 2.0 and later.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_NOANIMATION
member.summary: A window created with this style does not show animated exploding and imploding rectangles, and does not have a button on the taskbar. Supported in Windows CE versions 2.0 and later.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_NOPARENTNOTIFY
member.summary: Specifies that a child window created with this style does not send the WM_PARENTNOTIFY message to its parent window when it is created or destroyed.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW
member.summary: Combines the WS_EX_CLIENTEDGE and WS_EX_WINDOWEDGE styles.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_PALETTEWINDOW
member.summary: Combines the WS_EX_WINDOWEDGE, WS_EX_TOOLWINDOW, and WS_EX_TOPMOST styles.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_RIGHT
member.summary: The window has generic "right-aligned" properties. This depends on the window class. This style has an effect only if the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading-order alignment; otherwise, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_RIGHTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: Vertical scroll bar (if present) is to the right of the client area. This is the default.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_RTLREADING
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading-order alignment, the window text is displayed using right-to-left reading-order properties. For other languages, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_STATICEDGE
member.summary: Creates a window with a three-dimensional border style intended to be used for items that do not accept user input.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_TOOLWINDOW
member.summary: Creates a tool window; that is, a window intended to be used as a floating toolbar. A tool window has a title bar that is shorter than a normal title bar, and the window title is drawn using a smaller font. A tool window does not appear in the taskbar or in the dialog that appears when the user presses ALT+TAB. If a tool window has a system menu, its icon is not displayed on the title bar. However, you can display the system menu by right-clicking or by typing ALT+SPACE.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_TOPMOST
member.summary: Specifies that a window created with this style should be placed above all non-topmost windows and should stay above them, even when the window is deactivated. To add or remove this style, use the SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_TRANSPARENT
member.summary: Specifies that a window created with this style should not be painted until siblings beneath the window (that were created by the same thread) have been painted. The window appears transparent because the bits of underlying sibling windows have already been painted. To achieve transparency without these restrictions, use the SetWindowRgn function.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_WINDOWEDGE
member.summary: Specifies that a window has a border with a raised edge.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyleExtended.WS_EX_NONE
member.summary: Additional value for Completeness

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_BORDER
member.summary: Creates a window that has a thin-line border.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_CAPTION
member.summary: Creates a window that has a title bar (includes the WS_BORDER style).

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_CHILD
member.summary: Creates a child window. This style cannot be used with the WS_POPUP style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_CHILDWINDOW
member.summary: Same as the WS_CHILD style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_CLIPSIBLINGS
member.summary: Clips child windows relative to each other; that is, when a particular child window receives a WM_PAINT message, the WS_CLIPSIBLINGS style clips all other overlapping child windows out of the region of the child window to be updated. If WS_CLIPSIBLINGS is not specified and child windows overlap, it is possible, when drawing within the client area of a child window, to draw within the client area of a neighboring child window.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_DISABLED
member.summary: Creates a window that is initially disabled. A disabled window cannot receive input from the user.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_DLGFRAME
member.summary: Creates a window that has a border of a style typically used with dialog boxes. A window with this style cannot have a title bar.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_GROUP
member.summary: Specifies the first control of a group of controls. The group consists of this first control and all controls defined after it, up to the next control with the WS_GROUP style. The first control in each group usually has the WS_TABSTOP style so that the user can move from group to group. The user can subsequently change the keyboard focus from one control in the group to the next control in the group by using the direction keys.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_HSCROLL
member.summary: Creates a window that has a horizontal scroll bar.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_ICONIC
member.summary: Creates a window that is initially minimized. Same as the WS_MINIMIZE style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_MAXIMIZE
member.summary: Creates a window that is initially maximized.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_MAXIMIZEBOX
member.summary: Creates a window that has a Maximize button. Cannot be combined with the WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_MINIMIZE
member.summary: Creates a window that is initially minimized. Same as the WS_ICONIC style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_MINIMIZEBOX
member.summary: Creates a window that has a Minimize button. Cannot be combined with the WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_OVERLAPPED
member.summary: Creates an overlapped window. An overlapped window has a title bar and a border. Same as the WS_TILED style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW
member.summary: Creates an overlapped window with the WS_OVERLAPPED, WS_CAPTION, WS_SYSMENU, WS_THICKFRAME, WS_MINIMIZEBOX, and WS_MAXIMIZEBOX styles. Same as the WS_TILEDWINDOW style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_POPUP
member.summary: Creates a pop-up window. This style cannot be used with the WS_CHILD style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_POPUPWINDOW
member.summary: Creates a pop-up window with WS_BORDER, WS_POPUP, and WS_SYSMENU styles. The WS_CAPTION and WS_POPUPWINDOW styles must be combined to make the window menu visible.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_SIZEBOX
member.summary: Creates a window that has a sizing border. Same as the WS_THICKFRAME style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_SYSMENU
member.summary: Creates a window that has a Close (X) button in the non-client area.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_TABSTOP
member.summary: Specifies a control that can receive the keyboard focus when the user presses the TAB key. Pressing the TAB key changes the keyboard focus to the next control with the WS_TABSTOP style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_THICKFRAME
member.summary: Creates a window that has a sizing border. Same as the WS_SIZEBOX style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_TILED
member.summary: Creates an overlapped window. An overlapped window has a title bar and a border. Same as the WS_OVERLAPPED style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_TILEDWINDOW
member.summary: Creates an overlapped window with the WS_OVERLAPPED, WS_CAPTION, WS_SYSMENU, WS_THICKFRAME, WS_MINIMIZEBOX, and WS_MAXIMIZEBOX styles. Same as the WS_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW style.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_VISIBLE
member.summary: Creates a window that is initially visible.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Win32.Win32Window.WindowStyle.WS_VSCROLL
member.summary: Creates a window that has a vertical scroll bar.

This exception is thrown in situations where calling code violates a "best practice". If you get this exception, it is advised that you consider rearchitecting the calling code.
New in v1.1

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.EnumEx
member.summary: Provides helper functions for Enumerations.
member.remarks: Extends the System.Enum Class.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.EnumEx.GetName(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the name of the constant in the specified enumeration that has the specified value.
member.param: An enumeration type.
The value of a particular enumerated constant in terms of its underlying type.
member.returns: A string containing the name of the enumerated constant in enumType whose value is value, or null if no such constant is found.
member.exception: enumType is not an System.Enum. -or- value is neither of type enumType nor does it have the same underlying type as enumType.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.EnumEx.GetNames(System.Type)
member.summary: Retrieves an array of the names of the constants in a specified enumeration.
member.param: An enumeration type.
member.returns: A string array of the names of the constants in enumType. The elements of the array are sorted by the values of the enumerated constants.
member.exception: enumType parameter is not an System.Enum
member.example: The follow example shows how to enumerate the members of the System.DayOfWeek enumeration by adding them to a ComboBox:- [Visual Basic] Dim thisDOW As New DayOfWeek For Each thisDOW In OpenNETCF.Enum.GetValues(Type.GetType("System.DayOfWeek")) ComboBox1.Items.Add(thisDOW) Next [C#] foreach(DayOfWeek thisdow in OpenNETCF.Enum.GetValues(typeof(DayOfWeek))) { comboBox1.Items.Add(thisdow); }

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.EnumEx.GetUnderlyingType(System.Type)
member.summary:
Returns the underlying type of the specified enumeration.
New in v1.1
member.param: An enumeration type.
member.returns: The underlying of enumType.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.EnumEx.GetValues(System.Type)
member.summary: Retrieves an array of the values of the constants in a specified enumeration.
member.param: An enumeration type.
member.returns: An System.Array of the values of the constants in enumType. The elements of the array are sorted by the values of the enumeration constants.
member.exception: enumType parameter is not an System.Enum

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.EnumEx.IsDefined(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary:
Returns an indication whether a constant with a specified value exists in a specified enumeration.
New in v1.1
member.param: An enumeration type.
The value or name of a constant in enumType.
member.returns: true if a constant in enumType has a value equal to value; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Converts the string representation of the name or numeric value of one or more enumerated constants to an equivalent enumerated object.
member.param: The of the enumeration.
A string containing the name or value to convert.
member.returns: An object of type enumType whose value is represented by value.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.EnumEx.Parse(System.Type,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of the name or numeric value of one or more enumerated constants to an equivalent enumerated object. A parameter specifies whether the operation is case-sensitive.
member.param: The of the enumeration.
A string containing the name or value to convert.
If true, ignore case; otherwise, regard case.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx
member.summary: Extends the functionality of

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.GetFolderPath(OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder)
member.summary: Gets the path to the system special folder identified by the specified enumeration.
member.param: An enumerated constant that identifies a system special folder.
member.returns: The path to the specified system special folder, if that folder physically exists on your computer; otherwise, the empty string (""). A folder will not physically exist if the operating system did not create it, the existing folder was deleted, or the folder is a virtual directory, such as My Computer, which does not correspond to a physical path.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.GetLogicalDrives
member.summary:
Returns an array of string containing the names of the logical drives on the current computer.
New in v1.2
member.returns: An array of string where each element contains the name of a logical drive.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.NewLine
member.summary: Gets the newline string defined for this environment.
member.value: A string containing "\r\n".
member.remarks: The property value is a constant customized specifically for the current platform. This value is automatically appended to text when using WriteLine methods, such as Console.WriteLine.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SystemDirectory
member.summary: Gets the fully qualified path of the system directory.
member.value: A string containing a directory path.
member.remarks: An example of the value returned is the string "\Windows".

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.PlatformName

member.remarks:
Valid values include:-
PocketPCPocket PC device or Emulator
SmartPhoneSmartphone 2003 Device or Emulator
CEPC platformWindows CE.NET Emulator Additional platform types will have other names. Useful when writing library code targetted at multiple platforms.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder
member.summary: Specifies enumerated constants used to retrieve directory paths to system special folders.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.Programs
member.summary: The directory that contains the user's program groups.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.Personal
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for documents. (Not supported in Pocket PC and Pocket PC 2002 - "\My Documents").

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.Favorites
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for the user's favorite items.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.Startup
member.summary: The directory that corresponds to the user's Startup program group. The system starts these programs whenever a user starts Windows CE.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.Recent
member.summary: The directory that contains the user's most recently used documents. Not supported on Windows Mobile.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.StartMenu
member.summary: The directory that contains the Start menu items.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.DesktopDirectory
member.summary: The directory used to physically store file objects on the desktop. Do not confuse this directory with the desktop folder itself, which is a virtual folder. Not supported on Windows Mobile.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.Fonts
member.summary: The Fonts folder.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.ApplicationData
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for application-specific data for the current user. Not supported on Windows Mobile.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.Windows
member.summary: The Windows folder. Not supported by Pocket PC and Pocket PC 2002.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.EnvironmentEx.SpecialFolder.ProgramFiles
member.summary: The program files directory.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.GuidEx
member.summary: Represents a globally unique identifier (GUID).
member.remarks: A GUID is a 128-bit integer (16 bytes) that can be used across all computers and networks wherever a unique identifier is required. Such an identifier has a very low probability of being duplicated.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.GuidEx.Empty
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.GuidEx.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified array of bytes.
member.param: A 16 element byte array containing values with which to initialize the GUID.
member.exception: is .
is not 16 bytes long.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.GuidEx.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the value represented by the specified string.
member.param: A that contains a GUID in one of the following formats('d' represents a hexadecimal digit whose case is ignored): 32 contiguous digits: dddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddd -or- Groups of 8, 4, 4, 4, and 12 digits with hyphens between the groups. The entire GUID can optionally be enclosed in matching braces or parentheses: dddddddd-dddd-dddd-dddd-dddddddddddd -or- {dddddddd-dddd-dddd-dddd-dddddddddddd} -or- (dddddddd-dddd-dddd-dddd-dddddddddddd) -or- Groups of 8, 4, and 4 digits, and a subset of eight groups of 2 digits, with each group prefixed by "0x" or "0X", and separated by commas. The entire GUID, as well as the subset, is enclosed in matching braces: {0xdddddddd, 0xdddd, 0xdddd,{0xdd,0xdd,0xdd,0xdd,0xdd,0xdd,0xdd,0xdd}} All braces, commas, and "0x" prefixes are required. All embedded spaces are ignored. All leading zeroes in a group are ignored. The digits shown in a group are the maximum number of meaningful digits that can appear in that group. You can specify from 1 to the number of digits shown for a group. The specified digits are assumed to be the low order digits of the group. If you specify more digits for a group than shown, the high-order digits are ignored.
member.exception: is .
The format of is invalid.
